Title:
Molecular Phylogenetics and Piercer Evolution in the
Bug-Killing Flies (Diptera: Tachinidae: Phasiinae)
Abstract:
Phasiinae (Diptera: Tachinidae) are endoparasitoid flies
that attack Heteroptera, including a multitude of agricultural pests. A
phylogenetically informed classification of the Phasiinae has eluded
systematists for over a century, primarily because of the conflicting
character states and confusing morphology of certain taxa that indicate
potential placement within other subfamilies. The unstable nature of
phasiine taxonomy discourages important research into their
classification, life history, and potential use in biological control.
In hopes of resolving several longstanding taxonomic debates and
encouraging future research into this important group of parasitoids,
the first molecular systematic analysis of the Phasiinae is presented,
including 128 worldwide taxa (80 genera) and approximately 7.6 kilobases
of nuclear data representing four genes. Special emphasis is placed on
the resolution of taxonomically ambiguous groups. The resulting robustly
supported phylogenetic trees (ML/Bayesian) are used to trace the
evolution of significant adaptive traits within the Tachinidae and test
hypotheses about the classification of Phasiinae. Subfamily placements
of the taxa Eutherini, Epigrimyiini, Litophasia, Strongygastrini, and
Parerigonini are confidently resolved, the former three within Dexiinae
and the latter two within Phasiinae. The phylogenetic position of the
Imitomyiini is more difficult to decipher, but analyses tentatively
place the tribe within Phasiinae. The Phasiinae are divided into ten
distinct lineages, with genera traditionally placed within the tribes
Phasiini and Parerigonini being distributed among multiple clades.
Ancestral state reconstruction suggests that piercing structures used to
insert eggs directly into host tissues have evolved independantly in a
number of groups, but have also been lost or reduced in several
lineages. A single potentially unequivocal morphological synapomorphy of
Phasiinae, an elongated medial plate of the hypandrium in males, is
identified.
